tags: i said i was done talking about this but im annoyed
summary: Being frustrated with the show is one thing, but killing eve is not queerbaiting. Like...we have canon gay characters....
body: Being frustrated with the show is one thing, but killing eve is not queerbaiting. Like…we have canon gay characters. Villanelle has been with multiple women. It’s not baiting just because the leads haven’t gotten together yet. there’s a ton of romantic tension already (and it’s not subtext!!!). They’ve both admitted the attraction, villanelle even said she loved her for crying out loud. It’s just not a cutesy romance story and was never meant to be one, we knew that going into it. I think that’s what Sandra was trying to say in the interview

They’ve both admitted the attraction, villanelle even said she loved her for crying out loud. It’s just not a cutesy romance story and was never meant to be one, we knew that going into it. I think that’s what Sandra was trying to say in the interview

They’ve both admitted the attraction, villanelle even said she loved her for crying out loud. It’s just not a cutesy romance story and was never meant to be one, we knew that going into it. I think that’s what Sandra was trying to say in the interview

summary: The actor’s breezy, offhand comedy and spot-on timing married with her attention to detail—the way Eve holds her handbag (not...
caption:
The actor’s breezy, offhand comedy and spot-on timing married with her attention to detail—the way Eve holds her handbag (not the same as how Oh would hold it, mind you), how she knots her brow in thought, how she uses her voice—show that Oh puts in the work. Speaking on how exactly she does it, she admits is “a little dangerous” and better done over a glass of wine than in a setting where words become “codified” on paper, but ultimately, it’s a deep dive she’s up for, even if cautiously. “It’s just naming those things that are unnameable,” she explains. “You don’t want anything—even in your own mind—to start solidifying.” There’s a mystery to good acting that should remain, Oh agrees, but curiosity about the process is valid, especially from fellow actors—hence her willingness to discuss it.

SANDRA OH FOR BACKSTAGE MAGAZINE, JUNE 2019

reblog.comment:

SANDRA OH FOR BACKSTAGE MAGAZINE, JUNE 2019

Speaking on how exactly she does it, she admits is “a little dangerous” and better done over a glass of wine than in a setting where words become “codified” on paper, but ultimately, it’s a deep dive she’s up for, even if cautiously. “It’s just naming those things that are unnameable,” she explains. “You don’t want anything—even in your own mind—to start solidifying.” There’s a mystery to good acting that should remain, Oh agrees, but curiosity about the process is valid, especially from fellow actors—hence her willingness to discuss it.

SANDRA OH FOR BACKSTAGE MAGAZINE, JUNE 2019
trail.content:
The actor’s breezy, offhand comedy and spot-on timing married with her attention to detail—the way Eve holds her handbag (not the same as how Oh would hold it, mind you), how she knots her brow in thought, how she uses her voice—show that Oh puts in the work. Speaking on how exactly she does it, she admits is “a little dangerous” and better done over a glass of wine than in a setting where words become “codified” on paper, but ultimately, it’s a deep dive she’s up for, even if cautiously. “It’s just naming those things that are unnameable,” she explains. “You don’t want anything—even in your own mind—to start solidifying.” There’s a mystery to good acting that should remain, Oh agrees, but curiosity about the process is valid, especially from fellow actors—hence her willingness to discuss it.

SANDRA OH FOR BACKSTAGE MAGAZINE, JUNE 2019

summary: I initially wasn’t going to say anything about that Gay Times article but it was irritating me so, to make a point about how...
body:
I initially wasn’t going to say anything about that Gay Times article but it was irritating me so, to make a point about how easy it is to manipulate meaning in written media, here’s this: 

This is the Gay Times article, almost verbatim. I changed very little and kept every quote. And yet with just a couple changes this article now has an entirely different, much more positive meaning. Take a breath everyone.

The first season of Killing Eve took the world by storm and left audiences eagerly awaiting its return for a second outing.

Alongside the dangerous game of cat and mouse between investigator Eve and murderess Villanelle, fans began to question if the show could explore the sexuality of its leading ladies. And could that possibly mean a romance together?

It’s a discussion that the show’s star, Golden Globe winner and SNL host Sandra Oh was quick point out that although it’s an important aspect of the series, it is not a “focus or a message” for the show.

Although fans might want the show to tackle the importance of representation and provide an opportunity for wider discussion of LGBTQ identity, Sandra doesn’t think that’s the show’s sole purpose. “You guys are tricky because you want to make it into something… but it just isn’t,” Sandra – who plays MI5 security officer Eve Polastri – said on the phone from New York.

“That’s also why I think sexuality and discovery of the wider reaches of sexuality is the theme of the show – why it’s interesting to people. It’s not one thing or another.”

And for Sandra, Killing Eve’s approach elsewhere in the show is perhaps what connects so well to LGBTQ audiences: “The fluidity, even in the questioning that I know Eve really really carries, is what I think people can truly relate to. We are not saying one thing or another because people are not one thing or another.”

She pauses: “I’m only going to focus in on the truth of what we are doing.”

The same can be said for her British co-star Jodie Comer, who plays the murderous yet likeable Villanelle, who explains that her character’s openness to life is something she thinks has connected with the audience.

“I think what people have enjoyed was the freedom of these women, but especially with Villanelle of asking how she feels and expressing it, and not apologising,” says Jodie. “I think that’s what people have enjoyed the most and what many women can relate to within these two women.”

Sandra is clear that if anybody can feel empowered or represented by Eve or Villanelle, then that’s “the best”.

“If what we’re doing regarding these characters reaches people who have not felt represented in that kind of what, it’s absolutely the best mark to hit because you just want to connect with people.”

Jodie added Villanelle’s sexuality was actually never explicitly discussed during the development of her character.

“I think what I love as well is that Villanelle’s sexuality was never discussed – it was who she was and I love that,” she tells us. “It is who she is and that was that.”

Responding to Jodie, Sandra continues: “And I think that’s how the show has moved on. No one needs to focus on or put quotations around things, with it being sexuality or race. You don’t have to put quotations around things because that’s actually not how we live. I think that’s one way that people responded.”

reblog.comment:

You don’t have to put quotations around things because that’s actually not how we live. I think that’s one way that people responded.”

summary: “When a writer is in the midst of the formation, you’re able to ask them questions that link you to the character. It’s...
body: “When a writer is in the midst of the formation, you’re able to ask them questions that link you to the character. It’s important to have a relationship that’s physical, eye-to-eye, because I do believe that something starts happening with everyone.” X

reblog.comment: “When a writer is in the midst of the formation, you’re able to ask them questions that link you to the character. It’s important to have a relationship that’s physical, eye-to-eye, because I do believe that something starts happening with everyone.” X

trail.content_raw: “When a writer is in the midst of the formation, you’re able to ask them questions that link you to the character. It’s important to have a relationship that’s physical, eye-to-eye, because I do believe that something starts happening with everyone.” X
trail.content: “When a writer is in the midst of the formation, you’re able to ask them questions that link you to the character. It’s important to have a relationship that’s physical, eye-to-eye, because I do believe that something starts happening with everyone.” X
